abstract.p: Oakland Athletics defeat Detroit Tigers, 9-5; roundup of other American League game scores (M)3

block.p: Jason Giambi set another milestone yesterday as the host Oakland Athletics ended a six-game losing streak.
Giambi hit his 30th home run and Ben Grieve added a three-run homer, leading the A's over the Detroit Tigers, 9-5.
Jason Giambi set another milestone yesterday as the host Oakland Athletics ended a six-game losing streak.
Giambi hit his 30th home run and Ben Grieve added a three-run homer, leading the A's over the Detroit Tigers, 9-5.

Matt Stairs hit a sacrifice fly in the second and Giambi hit a two-run homer in the third, giving him 101 runs batted in. Giambi joined Jose Canseco (1986-88) as the only Oakland players to drive in 100 runs in three straight years.
''It sounds like a broken record, but he's having a great year,'' A's Manager Art Howe said. ''He's doing the job day in and day out, and giving us opportunities to win.''
Giambi also reached 100 R.B.I. quicker than any player in Oakland history, bettering Reggie Jackson's 1973 pace, when he got his 100th R.B.I. on Aug. 18.
Tim Hudson (13-4) took a one-hit shutout into the seventh, but wound up allowing four runs and five hits in six-plus innings. Hudson is 4-0 against Detroit in four career starts.
WHITE SOX 5, DEVIL RAYS 4: Carlos Lee homered and drove in the go-ahead run with a 10th-inning sacrifice fly as Chicago beat host Tampa Bay.
Magglio Ordonez, who went 4 for 4 with two R.B.I., opened the 10th with a single off Roberto Hernandez (3-4).
Ordonez went to second on catcher Mike DiFelice's passed ball, moved to third on a balk and scored on Lee's homer to left field.
Mark Buehrle (3-1) allowed one hit in one scoreless inning. Keith Foulke got three outs for his 21st save in 25 opportunities.

The Devil Rays scored once in the eighth to tie it at 4-4. Greg Vaughn drew a two-out walk from Bob Howry, reliever Kelly Wunsch walked Fred McGriff on four pitches and Jose Guillen hit an R.B.I. single that deflected off third baseman Herbert Perry.
INDIANS 5, MARINERS 4: Bartolo Colon struck out eight in seven innings, allowing just four hits as Cleveland recorded its eighth victory in 10 games.

With the score at 2-2 in the fifth, Cleveland went ahead when Kenny Lofton doubled to center off host Seattle's John Halama (10-6) and scored on a double error -- first Mike Cameron kicked the ball, then shortstop Alex Rodriguez's relay throw was wild, going past third baseman Carlos Guillen and pitcher John Halama.
David Segui had a two-run single in the eighth off Brett Tomko, who loaded the bases on walks to Lofton and Omar Vizquel, a sacrifice by Roberto Alomar and an intentional walk to Manny Ramirez.
Bob Wickman got three outs for his fifth save in six chances, his fifth since Cleveland acquired him from Milwaukee on July 28.
TWINS 6, BLUE JAYS 3: The rookie Mark Redman pitched six strong innings and Torii Hunter hit a two-run homer for host Minnesota.
Redman (11-5) allowed one run, six hits, struck out three and walked one for the Twins, who have won six of their last 10.

The left-hander, who leads A.L. rookies in victories, earned run average (4.43), strikeouts (99) and innings pitched (126), was in trouble just once -- in the second inning -- when Toronto got three of its hits and its only run off Redman.
LaTroy Hawkins pitched two innings and struck out four of six batters to earn his eighth save in as many chances.

Hunter, recalled from Class AAA Salt Lake City on July 29 to shore up Minnesota's outfield, hit an 0-2 pitch from Toronto starter Esteban Loaiza (6-9) over the right-field wall in the third with one on to give the Twins a 5-1 lead.
RANGERS 6, RED SOX 3: Ricky Ledee hit a fourth-inning grand slam to back Rick Helling and host Texas beat the Red Sox, Boston's fifth loss in seven games.

Ledee homered in the fourth off Tim Wakefield (6-7). It was his second career slam, his 10th homer of the season and his first since Texas acquired him from Cleveland on July 28. Ledee added a sacrifice fly in the eighth for his fifth R.B.I., matching his career high.
Helling (14-8) allowed one run and four hits in seven innings, struck out five and walked three, improving to 7-1 in his last 10 starts.
ORIOLES 12, ROYALS 11: Albert Belle hit a two-out, two-run homer to cap a four-run ninth inning, and Baltimore overcame Jermaine Dye's six R.B.I. for host Kansas City.
Kansas City trailed by 8-3 in the fifth before taking an 11-8 lead in the eighth on a two-run single by Dye off Buddy Groom (5-3) and Mark Quinn's R.B.I. single.
Delino DeShields hit a two-run single off Jerry Spradlin in the ninth and Belle followed with a homer off Ricky Bottalico (7-4), who blew a save for the seventh time in 20 chances.
Brian Kohlmeier pitched the ninth for his third save in three chances.
Dye, who matched his R.B.I. high, was 3 for 5 with a pair of homers, raising his total to a career-high 28, one more than he hit last year.
